lib.networks.parameter_init module

lib.networks.parameter_init.constant_init(module: torch.nn.Module, val: float, bias: float = 0) → None[source]
lib.networks.parameter_init.normal_init(module: torch.nn.Module, mean: float = 0, std: float = 1, bias: float = 0) → None[source]
lib.networks.parameter_init.trunc_normal_(tensor, mean: float = 0.0, std: float = 1.0, a: float = -2.0, b: float = 2.0)[source]

Fills the input Tensor with values drawn from a truncated normal distribution. The values are effectively drawn from the normal distribution \(\mathcal{N}(\text{mean}, \text{std}^2)\) with values outside \([a, b]\) redrawn until they are within the bounds. The method used for generating the random values works best when \(a \leq \text{mean} \leq b\). Modified from https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/master/torch/nn/init.py :param tensor: an n-dimensional torch.Tensor. :type tensor: torch.Tensor :param mean: the mean of the normal distribution. :type mean: float :param std: the standard deviation of the normal distribution. :type std: float :param a: the minimum cutoff value. :type a: float :param b: the maximum cutoff value. :type b: float

lib.networks.parameter_init.trunc_normal_init(module: torch.nn.Module, mean: float = 0, std: float = 1, a: float = -2, b: float = 2, bias: float = 0) → None[source]
